Hare Krishna and welcome back to today's episode of the Mahabharata.
In the previous episode we have seen how after the game of dice, good sense prevailed over
Dhritarashtra and he returned all those things which had been wrongfully, by way of cheating,
had been taken away from the Pandavas by Shakuni and Duryodhana.
After the game of dice, after Dhritarashtra returned everything and he spoke a few conciliatory
words to Draupadi and to the Pandavas, he dissolved the assembly and everyone left the
assembly hall.
After everyone left the assembly hall, a few people remained back and they were looking
at each other and who are these people and what were their thoughts.
Stay with us today to learn about that.
The Pandavas after leaving the assembly, they stepped out of the place and they got onto
their chariots and they left Hastinapura.
They drove back to Indraprastha.
Their hearts were heavy.
Their thoughts were filled with all those words of insults and the attempt to disrobe
Draupadi.
The Pandavas were still fresh in their hearts and the wounds were still festering.
The Pandavas, although at that moment, at that point of time, there was no way they
could vent out their anger and frustration, carrying these heavy thoughts in their mind,
they were going back to Indraprastha.
After they had gone out of Hastinapura and they had travelled some distance, they were
told that somebody was coming on a horseback trying to catch up with them.
Soon the person who was on horseback caught up with the Pandavas and they saw that this
person on horseback was one of the servants from the Hastinapura palace.
This servant, he came with a message to Yudhishthira Maharaj and to the Pandavas.
He said,
Yudhishthira Maharaj.
Yudhishthira Maharaj.
Yudhishthira Maharaj.
The Pandavas were surprised.
They, after all that had happened, they just, just left the assembly and they had set out
back to Indraprastha.
But suddenly this messenger turned up and this messenger said that he was carrying a
message for the Pandavas from Dhritarashtra.
What was this message that Dhritarashtra had chosen to send to the Pandavas?
Actually what had happened?

so these were the feelings of dushasana
duryodhana also felt alike but there was nothing they could do
what to do. But if the matter had been just that, that the Pandavas had been returned
their kingdom, it would not have been much of an issue. But the issue was that the Pandavas
had been subjected to such great insults that they were not going to keep quiet. On some
pretext or the other, Duryodhana was afraid they would take a war with the Kauravas. Then
it would be very difficult because Duryodhana very well knew the prowess of the Pandavas.
All along until now, he had been trying to avoid direct confrontation but to somehow
through some cunning means, somehow cheat them of their kingdom and cheat them of their
royal authority. These were his plans. So all along he had always avoided direct confrontation
because Duryodhana knew that if he were to directly face the Pandavas in battle,
he would not be able to succeed. Chakuni then spoke up and he told Duryodhana whatever
happened, happened. Now you see, we cannot directly engage in a battle with the Pandavas.
We cannot afford that. Somehow Hastinapura was not ours. We have got it in our hand.
Now if we get into a battle with the Pandavas and lose Hastinapura also in our greed for Indraprastha,
then we are left with, we are neither here nor there. So we have to think of something
immediately. Then Chakuni said, I have got a plan by which we can still save the situation.
What is that? Chakuni said, somehow if we convince the Pandavas again for another game of dice,
then somehow we can manage to win back whatever we want.
Now neither Karna nor Duryodhana nor Dushyasana were in favor of a direct fight with the Pandavas
because everybody knew they could not win. What Chakuni was proposing seemed to be the
only solution. But then how to do it? How could the Pandavas again be brought back to
another game of dice? Duryodhana took the task upon himself and went and met Dhritarashtra.
He spoke to his father and he tried various ways to convince Dhritarashtra. Dhritarashtra was like,
no, no, why? He was not in favor of it. He said, already one game of dice, so much bad blood has
happened between the two of you. One more game of dice, there will be no stopping the, stopping a
war between the two of you. So Dhritarashtra was not in favor. Finally Duryodhana told Dhritarashtra,
my dear father,
Dhritarashtra has gone out of control. Sooner or later the Pandavas will gather some, on some
pretext or the other, they will gather an army and attack us. We have to preempt this. So the
only preemptive fight that we can do is, you have to call them for another game of dice and we have
to ensure that we win back the kingdom. Now, if we don't do that, we have to call them for another
game of dice. If we don't do that, then what, what are we doing? We are inviting trouble. Because it is, the
Pandavas are now, are now like snakes who have been trampled upon. Once we trample upon a snake's head,
after that you cannot think of just walking away silently. The snake will follow you and it will
attack you and it will try to bite you. The only way is, you have to defend yourself. If you have,
you have to take protective measures. Duryodhana, hence,
told Dhritarashtra that the only way to take a preemptive action is to prevent a battle from
happening, which can only be done if the Pandavas are somehow sent out away from Indraprastha and we
have to send them in exile somewhere. And for that, the only way is to engage them again in another
game of dice. Not only this, Duryodhana told Dhritarashtra, let, let us engage them in a game
of dice and let's take this time.

Duryodhana told Dhritarashtra that the only way is to engage them again in another game of dice and let's take this time. And for that, the only way is to engage them again in another game of dice and let's take this time.

And if the Pandavas are in exile for a sufficient period of time, Duryodhana said, with all the wealth in Indraprastha and with all the kings, I will get all the kings on my side and then my power will become really strong and the Pandavas, whenever they come back, they will not be able to face us. They will not be able to withstand the power of my army.

Dhritarashtra, although he was hesitant, finally, Duryodhana's persuasive words finally overcame his hesitancy. So finally, Dhritarashtra agreed. And Dhritarashtra summoned the servant and sent him, dispatched him to order Yudhishthira for another game of dice.

When Dhritarashtra took this decision and this decision came to be that the message started spreading everywhere that Dhritarashtra has again called for one more game of dice, the news reached Gandhari's ears.
She came running to her husband and she said, I heard that you have called for one more game of dice. I have heard what Draupadi had to go through in that assembly.
It is unthinkable how Draupadi could have been subjected to such ignominy.
And somehow you salvage the situation by returning everything.
Now you have gone round the bend.
You are again calling for another game of dice.
Really, I mean, what do you think of yourself?
Do you understand the consequences of your action?
This is absolutely, what you are doing is absolutely wrong.
On the other hand, Gandhari, the mother of Duryodhana, she advised Dhritarasva.
On the other hand, please hand over the kingdom to the Pandavas and banish Duryodhana from the family.
You send him away from Hastinapura. Don't keep him here.
This was a mother's advice to Dhritarasva.
Duryodhana's own mother, she could see the evilness in Duryodhana.
And the righteousness of the Pandavas and she was fully in favour of the Pandavas and she said better to reject Duryodhana and avoid any sort of ill-will and fighting within the family.
But Dhritarasva, what was Dhritarasva's response?
He told Gandhari, you see Gandhari, whatever I have to do, I have done.
Now, whatever happens.
By the will of providence, let it happen.
I cannot help it.
And he walked off.
Now, Gandhari, what could she do?
She had tried her best.
She went back.
And finally, this messenger, despatched by Dhritarasva, had now reached the Pandavas and he was standing in front of Yudhishthira with the message from Dhritarasva.
What was the message?
The message was, the king is calling you, Yudhishthira Maharaja.
The king is calling you, Yudhishthira Maharaja.
For another game of dice.
Yudhishthira looked at his brothers and he said, I am helpless.
It is the duty of a Kshatriya never to say no to a challenge.
Over and above this, Dhritarasva is in the position of my father.
He is my elder.
He is ordering I cannot disobey him.
The other brothers in Draupadi, they also understood and fully well they empathized with Yudhishthira Maharaja's position.
And they could understand that there was hardly anything else they could do in the face of following the rules of Dharma.
Actually, what we have to understand is, there are rules of Dharma for protecting oneself.
And then there are higher rules.
There are secondary principles and there are higher principles.
At a very individual level, if I am very selfish, I take care of myself.
Now, I am not living alone in this society.
I am living in the midst of so many relatives, friends, servants, so many people are serving me, so many animals.
And there are so many demigods, devatas who are providing me so much facilities and conveniences in nature.
So, I am living in the midst of all of these things.
So, I have duty towards my own, taking care of my own welfare.
Then, I also have to think about higher principles.
Welfare of my family.
Then, welfare of my friends and relatives.
Welfare of the entire humankind.
Welfare of other animals.
Welfare of this earth.
Welfare of this environment.
We have responsibility towards all these things.
